frontmatter.title: Phase 1 üå≥ : Calibration of species in optimal conditions (monoculture + mesic soil + average and unchanging climate)

abbreviations.PnETSpeciesParameters: Parameter than then calls a list of species.
abbreviations.FolN: Foliar nitrogen content (in % by weight) for the leaves of the species.
abbreviations.SLWmax: Specific leaf weight at the top of the canopy.
abbreviations.SLWDel: Rate of change in the weight of the leaves from the top of the canopy (SLWmax) to each sublayer under the canopy.
abbreviations.MaxLAI: Maximum leaf area index (LAI) that a species can achieve in its lifetime (for an age cohort ?).
abbreviations.TOFol: Fraction of foliage biomass lost per year.
abbreviations.TORoot: Fraction of root biomass lost per year.
abbreviations.TOWood: Fraction of wood biomass lost per year.
abbreviations.AmaxA: Intercept of the relationship between foliar N and maximum net photosynthetic rate.
abbreviations.AmaxB: Slope of the relationship betwee foliar N and maximum net photosynthetic rate.
abbreviations.HalfSat: Half saturation light level for photosynthesis.
abbreviations.H1: Water stress parameter according to Feddes et al. (1978) (Fig. 59).
abbreviations.H2: Water stress parameter according to Feddes et al. (1978) (Fig. 59).
abbreviations.H3: Water stress parameter according to Feddes et al. (1978) (Fig. 59).
abbreviations.H4: Water stress parameter according to Feddes et al. (1978) (Fig. 59).
abbreviations.PsnAgeRed: Reduction factor of photosynthesis as the age of an age cohort increases.
abbreviations.LeafOnMinT: Minimum temperature for activate growing season.
abbreviations.PsnTMin: Minimum average daytime temperature for photosynthesis.
abbreviations.PsnTOpt: Optimal average daytime temperature for photosynthesis.
abbreviations.PsnTMax: Maximum average daytime temperature for photosynthesis.
abbreviations.ColTol: Cold tolerance (coldest temperature that the species can survive).
abbreviations.k (parameter): Canopy light attenuation constant (light extinction coefficient).
abbreviations.DNSC: Proportion of Non Structural (ressources) carbon from the total activate biomass of the cohort that will be maintained as long as net photosynthesis exceeds maintenance respiration.
abbreviations.FracBelowG: Fraction of non-foliar biomass that is allocated belowground (root pool).
abbreviations.EstMoist: Scaling parameter that changes the maximum expected value of fWater when computing the probability of establishment.
abbreviations.EstRad: Scaling parameter that changes the maximum expected value of fRad when computing the probability of establishment.
abbreviations.FracFol: Fraction of the active woody biomass (above or belowground) of a cohort that determines the amount of foliage maintained each year.
abbreviations.FrActWd: Shape parameter of the negative exponential function that calculates the amount of woody biomass that has active xylem capable of supporting foliage.
abbreviations.CO2HalfSatEff: Slope coefficient used to reduce HalfSat (= increase shade tolerance) as CO2 concentration increase.
abbreviations.CO2AMaxBEff: Proportional change in AmaxB at 550ppm CO2 relative to 350ppm.
abbreviations.O3StomataSens: Species susceptibility of the stomata to ozone-induced sluggishness.
abbreviations.O3GrowthSens: Species susceptibility to ozone-induced tissue damage.
abbreviations.MaxFolN: Controls the dynamic response of foliar nitrogen (FolN) to light.
abbreviations.FolNShape: Controls the dynamic response of foliar nitrogen (FolN) to light.
abbreviations.MaxFracFol: Controls the dynamic response of the fraction of Foliage (FracFol) to light.
abbreviations.FracFolShape: Controls the dynamic response of the fraction of Foliage (FracFol) to light.
abbreviations.LifeFrom: Specifies the life form (stature) of the species to determine the limits to the species major canopy layer.
abbreviations.MossScalar: Unit converter from biomass to depth in the case of a pseudo species (moss).
abbreviations.MaxCanopyLayer: Caps the number of canopy layers implemented in the model.
abbreviations.LayerThreshRatio: Define how age cohorts of a given species are grouped together into canopy layers. Correspond to the minimum ratio of cohort woody biomass density between two cohorts that will place them in different canopy layers.
abbreviations.PARunits: Indicates the units for PAR and HalfSat values. See Climate Input File for PAR and Species Parameters File for HalfSat.
abbreviations.IMAX: Defines the degree of subdivision into different canopy sublayers for each age cohort.
abbreviations.DVPD1: Coefficient for converting the vapor pressure deficit (VPD) into a reduction factor for photosynthesis caused by water pressure (fDVPD).
abbreviations.DVPD2: Coefficient for converting the vapor pressure deficit (VPD) into a reduction factor for photosynthesis caused by water pressure (fDVPD).
abbreviations.BFolResp: Define the Base Foliar Respiration Fraction (the foliar respiration as a fraction of the maximum photosynthetic rate).
abbreviations.MaintResp: Represents the loss of Non Structural Carbon (NSC) due to maintenance respiration as a fraction of the active wood biomass of the cohort.
abbreviations.Q10: Coefficient of the Q10 relationship to compute the foliar respiration.
abbreviations.FolLignin: Mass fraction of lignin in foliage tissue.
abbreviations.KWdLit: Annual decomposition rate of woody litter (decay constant k in equations).
abbreviations.InitialNSC: Amount of Non Structural Carbon assigned to newly established cohorts.
abbreviations.CFracBiomass: Carbon fraction of biomass by weight in an age cohort.
abbreviations.PrecipEvents: Number of precipitation events during a month.
abbreviations.PrecipEventsWithReplacement: Defines the logic of assignation of the precipitation from a precipitation event to the canopy sub layers.
abbreviations.ETExtCoeff: Canopy extinction coefficient to reduce soil water evaporation as LAI increases (because of shadow created by the canopy ?).
abbreviations.RETCropCoeff: Coefficient that scales the reference evapotranspiration (RET).
abbreviations.PreventEstablishment: Turns species establishment on new cells on or off.
abbreviations.Wythers: Turns the Wythers correction on or off.
abbreviations.DTEMP: Turns the PnET-II DTEMP temperature reduction factor on or off.
abbreviations.MaxPest: Tuning parameter to raise or lower the establishment probability of species by a same proportion.
abbreviations.AmaxFrac: Fraction of the early morning instantaneous photosynthetic rate that represents the mean daily photosynthetic rate.
abbreviations.InvertPest: Activates the optional inversion of the effect of fRad on the probability establishment as a function of HalfSat.
abbreviations.SoilIceDepth: Activates the optional simulation of soil ice depth and its effects on water leakage.
abbreviations.LeakageFrostDepth: Soil ice depth at which frozen soil no longer impedes soil drainage.
abbreviations.FrostFactor: Tuning parameter to adjust soil ice depth.
abbreviations.InitialCommunitiesSpinup: Specifies how the biomass of the initial age cohorts/communities in each cells are generated.
abbreviations.SpinupWaterStress: Activates waterlogging stress during spin up procedures.
abbreviations.Parallel: Specifies the number of CPU threads used for parallel execution.
abbreviations.CohortStacking: Specifies the canopy cohort processing method.
abbreviations.CanopySumScale: Scales the degree to which cumulativve canopy proportions cannot exceed 1.

children.value: Goal of this first calibration step

children.label: Goal of this first calibration step

children.value: The goal of this first calibration phase, as recommanded by

, is to calibrate the growth and mortality of a given tree species in ‚Äúideal‚Äù conditions. This means simulating a monoculture (no light competition with another species) on a mesic soil that retains water correctly (no drought, but no watterlogging either) and with a very mild, average historical climate (no extremes, especially in precipitations and temperatures).

By doing so, we can isolate the effect of the many parameters and factor that influence tree growth, and focus on the few parameters that should (on a theoritical level) influence tree growth and mortality in ideal conditions :

children.title: Fraction of the active woody biomass (above or belowground) of a cohort that determines the amount of foliage maintained each year.
Foliar nitrogen content (in % by weight) for the leaves of the species.
Fraction of wood biomass lost per year.
Fraction of root biomass lost per year.
Specific leaf weight at the top of the canopy.
Fraction of the active woody biomass (above or belowground) of a cohort that determines the amount of foliage maintained each year.

children.value: (pioneers species tend to have relatively high values)

children.title: Foliar nitrogen content (in % by weight) for the leaves of the species.

children.value: (pioneers species tend to have relatively high values)

children.title: Fraction of non-foliar biomass that is allocated belowground (root pool).

children.value: To make sure your species sees the conditions of the simulation as really ideal (so that you can, again, isolate the effect from other parameters), you can even put

children.title: Optimal average daytime temperature for photosynthesis.

children.value: for your species to a value matching the climate inputs during the three warmest months of the growing season. This will make it so that your species sees the temperatures in your climate file as optimal. This is not absolutly necessary.

Here, you will be trying to match a bit above the growth curves or estimates produced in your empirical data. This is become we‚Äôre simulating ideal conditions, including a mild climate and a good soil (SILO). But in reality data, species do not grow in ideal conditions.
Overall, as recommanded by the user guide, calibration is best done by modifying only

children.title: Foliar nitrogen content (in % by weight) for the leaves of the species.
Fraction of the active woody biomass (above or belowground) of a cohort that determines the amount of foliage maintained each year.
Shape parameter of the negative exponential function that calculates the amount of woody biomass that has active xylem capable of supporting foliage.
Specific leaf weight at the top of the canopy.

children.value: (to control gross foliage amount and LAI, which determines the ability to access light) as much as possible. But if you produce growth curve that are too far from your empirical data, you can always change the other parameters too.

Be certain to have solid initial estimates for all other parameters that will not be calibrated during this phase, so as to avoid as much as possible a counfounding effect that could result from problematic or uncorrect values for these parameters.

Be certain to have good weather data. Because biomass accumulation is ultimately limited by water, your precipitation inputs should not be much greater than is typical for your study area, especially for the results of your simulation to match your empirical data better.

, keep in mind that calibrating growth to strictly match empirical growth curves may cause competition behavior in the model that is unrealistic. As such, you may want to favor a shape that is somewhat consistent with other species that have the same growth strategy (e.g., pioneers v. shade-tolerants). This will be important for the next phase (calibrating competition outcomes).

the model equations may produce a curve shape that is somewhat different than your empirical curves (likely generated under specific conditions) and forcing the model to exactly match empirical curves may reduce its validity in landscape simulations. In particular, you should try to match the biomass accumulation where growth begins to plateau and produce relative rates of initial growth that reflect each species‚Äô growth strategy (i.e., continuum of pioneer v. shade-tolerant)
Everything here comes from my interpretation of the calibration tips in
. These are quite complex, so there might be oversimplifications/misunderstanding from my part. I‚Äôll try to rectify if I detect some problems.

Sub-phase 2 : Calibrating the beginning of the growth curve

children.label: Sub-phase 2 : Calibrating the beginning of the growth curve

children.title: Controls the dynamic response of the fraction of Foliage (FracFol) to light.
Controls the dynamic response of the fraction of Foliage (FracFol) to light.

children.value: The objective is to match the speed at which biomass accumulates towards the peak. This is crucial for competition further down the road, as species that can grow very fast will be more competitive.
Two elements can be used as targets here : your empirical data, and the targets of Wood biomass at age 14 (in g/m2) recommanded by
To match these targets, it is recommanded that you act on these two parameters :

Sub-phase 3 (optional) : mid-age depression of the growth curve for short-lived species

children.label: Sub-phase 3 (optional) : mid-age depression of the growth curve for short-lived species

children.title: Reduction factor of photosynthesis as the age of an age cohort increases.
Represents the loss of Non Structural Carbon (NSC) due to maintenance respiration as a fraction of the active wood biomass of the cohort.

children.value: Some short-lived tree species tend to growth fast at first, but then see their growth slowing down. As such, one might want to reduce growth at their mid-age so that their growth peak is reached more slowly. This can be done through

children.title: Reduction factor of photosynthesis as the age of an age cohort increases.

children.value: , which limits photosynthesis as a function of age. But be careful about the impact of

children.title: Reduction factor of photosynthesis as the age of an age cohort increases.

children.value: on the age of cohort mortality due to senescence (see next section).

children.title: Represents the loss of Non Structural Carbon (NSC) due to maintenance respiration as a fraction of the active wood biomass of the cohort.

children.value: to represent the fact that short-lived species tend to grow fast but have a higher maintenance respiration rate which will depress their growth after a while. Raising

children.title: Represents the loss of Non Structural Carbon (NSC) due to maintenance respiration as a fraction of the active wood biomass of the cohort.

children.value: will therefore depress the curve. But this will make your species more prone to competition mortality, making it more difficult for these species to co-exist together.

children.title: Reduction factor of photosynthesis as the age of an age cohort increases.

children.value: Longevity (LANDIS-II Core species parameter; is outside of PnET Succession)

The last phase of the curve to calibrate is the senescence phase, where the tree cohort grows older. At it grows, its maintenance cost (in carbon) will grow; but its photosynthesis will be reduced through a reduction factor, and will completly stop as the cohort reaches the ‚Äúlongevity‚Äù core species parameter for its species. This is how tree cohort die of old age in PnET-Succession : by becoming progressively unable to sustain their maintenance costs through photosynthesis.

As such, there are two targets that are being calibrated here : 1) the age where photosynthesis will start declining because of age, and 2) the age where the photosynthesis reduction factor will become so low that the cohort will die by lack of ressources. These two targets are shown on the following figure :

This is a comment; I had to find a way to resize the image in Jupyter lab.
That makes for a snippet a code that is more complex than I'd want. See https://github.com/jupyter/notebook/issues/1885.
The first target (initiation of decline) is defined in PnET with the parameter

children.title: Reduction factor of photosynthesis as the age of an age cohort increases.

children.value: , which controls when the photosynthesis reduction factor fAge starts declining, and how fast.
The second target (age of cohort death) is influenced by the start of the decline (first target), but also  with the ‚Äúlongevity‚Äù parameter given in the ‚ÄúCore‚Äù species parameter file (e.g.

). When the age of the cohort reaches the ‚Äúlongevity‚Äù parammeter, the photosynthesis reduction factor fAge will reach 0 (no more photosynthesis takes place). Of course, the cohort will most likely die before it reaches 0 because its photosynthesis will have been too low for too much time, which will have depleted its ressources before fAge reaches 0. As such, you should try to input a ‚Äúlongevity‚Äù parameter value in the species parameter file that will kill your cohort at the age you want (e.g. that correspond to empirical data) in interaction with your first target. Note again that the cohort will very likely die

As to where you can get estimates of these two targets (initation of decline and age of cohort death) for your species, this gets a bit complex. The decreasing part of the empirical biomass growth data that you might have used so far often contain the effect of other factors that affect tree morality including human harvesting, natural disturbance and diseases, and competition with other trees. However, as we are simulating tree growth in ideal conditions, we are trying to isolate the effect of senescence from these other factors. As such, the empirical biomass data you have will most likely not be a good target to match (as you will over-estimate senescence if you try to match them).
As such, there are several options to get the initiation of decline and age of cohort death. Here are some of them :

For the age of cohort death, you could try to obtain individual tree age data from sample plots of forest inventory, and find the 99th percentile (to avoid outlayers) of tree age for your species. This should give you a good estimate of the maximum age observed for this species, which should be as close as can be to something like a ‚Äúage of cohort death in ideal growth conditions‚Äù as we‚Äôre trying to find here.

Be careful of the reported values in the litterature for the longevity of the species. These are often expert opinion, and might represent what experts often see in the field, which is influenced by other causes of mortality (competition, climate, disturbances, etc.) that you don‚Äôt want to take into account here.
For the initiation of decline, you can :

Use reported values of longevity in the litterature, which are often the result of rule-of-thumb or expert opinion as noted above, but which can be interpreted as the initiation of decline; for the age of cohort death, you could rather use empirical values of maximum tree age (see above). This is the methodology used by Brian Sturtevant‚Äôs team.
Take a percentile of the tree ages from the same tree age data you used for the age of cohort death (see above); for example, 75th or 80th percentile.
Use a rule-of-thumb and set the initiation of decline to half or 3/4 of the age of cohort death.

children.title: Reduction factor of photosynthesis as the age of an age cohort increases.

children.value: in PnET (5), or the same value for every species.

children.title: Reduction factor of photosynthesis as the age of an age cohort increases.

children.value: for every species, on the basis that it will make it harder to understand and calibrate the competition between species (see next step).
If you have depressed the growth curve using

children.title: Reduction factor of photosynthesis as the age of an age cohort increases.

children.value: in the previous sub-phase 3, then you should‚Äôt change it at this step, and should rather focus in changing the value of longevity in the core species parameter file so that the age of cohort death is correct.
In this notebook, we will use the 99th percentile of empirical tree age data in Canada from sample plot data to set the age of cohort death for our species, and we will use the default value of

children.title: Reduction factor of photosynthesis as the age of an age cohort increases.

children.value: (5) to set the initiation of decline.
Source of empirical data for the Calibration

children.label: Source of empirical data for the Calibration

children.value:
# Will need to edit the PnET One Cell files to use the climate file created in 4. through the LANDIS-II climate library.
# Also need to edit eco1 in ecoregion parameters to give it SILO

# Create the scatter plot
# Get the current color cycle
from itertools import cycle
colours = cycle(['#a3be8c', '#5e81ac', '#bf616a', '#d08770', '#ebcb8b', '#2e3440', '#8fbcbb'])
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 8))
for province in dictOfResults_0:
    plt.scatter(dictOfResults_0[province][0], dictOfResults_0[province][1], alpha=0.6, s=8, c=next(colours), label = province)
plt.xlabel('Forest Age (years)')
plt.ylabel('Abies Balsamea Biomass (g/m2)')
plt.title(f'Relationship between Forest Age and Abies Balsamea Biomass - all cells with some Abies Balsamea biomass')
plt.grid(True, linestyle='--', alpha=0.7)
plt.legend()

# Add a trend line
# if len(age_sample) > 1:
#     z = np.polyfit(age_sample, abies_biomass_sample, 1)
#     p = np.poly1d(z)
#     age_range = np.linspace(age_sample.min(), age_sample.max(), 100)
#     plt.plot(age_range, p(age_range), "r--", alpha=0.8, linewidth=2)
#     plt.text(0.05, 0.95, f'y = {z[0]:.4f}x + {z[1]:.4f}', 
#              transform=plt.gca().transAxes, fontsize=12, 
#              bbox=dict(boxstyle="round,pad=0.3", facecolor="white", alpha=0.8))

plt.tight_layout()
plt.savefig('age_vs_abies_biomass.png', dpi=300)
plt.show()

Ameray_2023.html: Ameray, A., Cavard, X., & Bergeron, Y. (2023). Climate change may increase Quebec boreal forest productivity in high latitudes by shifting its current composition. Frontiers in Forests and Global Change, 6. 10.3389/ffgc.2023.1020305
